div.div: Feed response with search and sort params as supplied by user

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 118px; height: 1px; padding-top: 449px; margin-left: 412px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: left;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: #000000; line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;

div.div:
Search by
- title
- description
(Search may be exact or substring match)
Sort by
- title
- dateLastEdited
Response
- Total match count
- Matched documents

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 158px; height: 1px; padding-top: 25px; margin-left: 211px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: #000000; line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;
display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 268px; height: 1px; padding-top: 290px; margin-left: 401px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: #000000; line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;

div.div: Elasticsearch looks like a good candidate as we just want to search. However, on a large scale of data, we might need to have a separate persistant storage for CRUD tasks as elasticsearch is a search engine and it will present some obstacles for us while performing normal CRUD operations

switch.text: Elasticsearch looks like a good candidate as...

a.text: Viewer does not support full SVG 1.1
